key_title: Key to the species of Muehlenbeckia

Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Polygonaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Polygonaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G. (1996). Polygonaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves triangular to orbicular, no more than 4 times as long as wide; climbing, scrambling or prostrate plants
Leaves linear, at least 4 times as long as wide; more or less erect shrubs
Leaves mostly 2 cm long or more; flowers clustered, usually in slender spikes; twining or loosely scrambling lowland plants
Leaves less than 1 cm long, almost orbicular; flowers solitary (rarely 2 or 3 together) in upper axils; uncommon, wiry, mat-forming plant in rocky eastern ranges
Leaves more or less triangular in outline, truncate, hastate, or sagittate at base, narrowed and obtuse or acuminate at apex; nut wrinkled or warty
Leaves ovate to orbicular in outline, cordate (or occasionally truncate) at base, rounded, obtuse or emarginate at apex; nut wrinkled or smooth
Leaves membranous, acuminate at apex; perianth segments c. 1 mm long at anthesis; flowering axis slender, almost filiform; rare twiner of moist, far eastern forests
Leaves rather thick-textured, obtuse at apex; perianth segments c. 3 mm long or more at anthesis; flowering axis not filiform; near-coastal twiner of far west
Leaves and stems not glaucous; stems twining, slender except near base; nut longitudinally 3-ribbed, otherwise smooth; mostly coastal
Leaves and stems glaucous; stems spreading or weakly erect, thickish (5 mm diam. or more within c. 30 cm of branch-tips); nut transversely wrinkled; rare plant of rocky sites in east
